summary: This is a court order by Judge Alison J. Nathan granting a continuance of Ghislaine Maxwell's trial from July 2021 to fall 2021. The continuance is granted due to the government's late filing of an S2 Superseding Indictment, which added new charges and an alleged victim, requiring significant additional defense preparation. The order balances the defense's need for time against the public interest in a timely trial.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case, whose defense counsel requested a continuance of the trial date to prepare for new charges in a superseding indictment.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case who issued the order granting a short continuance of the trial until fall 2021.

persons.name: Judge Furman
persons.context: A judge presiding over a separate criminal matter involving lawyers who also represent Maxwell; his adjournment of a trial date is noted as potentially resolving a scheduling conflict.

connections.description: Judge Nathan is presiding over the criminal case against defendant Maxwell and ruled on her motion for a continuance.

events.title: Filing of S2 Superseding Indictment
events.description: The Government filed a superseding indictment adding new charges, extending the timeline of alleged conspiracies to 2004, and identifying a fourth alleged victim (Minor Victim-4).

events.title: Originally Scheduled Trial Start
events.description: The trial was originally scheduled to commence on this date before being adjourned.

events.title: Deadline for Joint Trial Date Proposal
events.description: The parties are ordered to meet and confer and jointly propose a new trial start date for fall 2021 by this date.

locations: United States District Court Southern District of New York
keyFacts: The S2 Superseding Indictment extended the timeline of the alleged conspiracies from through 1997 to 2004 and identified a fourth alleged victim, 'Minor Victim-4'.
The superseding indictment added two new charges: Count 5 (sex trafficking conspiracy 2001-2004) and Count 6 (sex trafficking of a minor or aiding and abetting).
Judge Nathan granted a continuance until fall 2021, rejecting both Maxwell's request for a January 2022 date and the Government's proposal for March 2022.
The court cited the COVID-19 pandemic as hampering defense preparation due to travel constraints and safety concerns.
The order emphasizes balancing the defense's need to prepare for new charges against the public and victims' interest in a trial without undue delay.
